[h1]Great atmosphere, but needs more reasons to cooperate[/h1]

[b]A beautiful and intense extraction shooter with amazing sound, smart AI, and impressive visual detail. I just wish there were more reasons for players to team up instead of shooting on sight.[/b]


The graphics and sound are great in this game. The sound design in particular stands out. You can easily tell when you might want to take a detour just because you hear a heavy drone flying nearby, or notice a probe with valuable loot standing close. It really adds tension and immersion to every step you take.

Atmosphere in this game is also quite breathtaking. The visuals, the way the story is told, the lighting, and the world design all work together perfectly. You really start to feel like you are living in this world. Sometimes I felt as if I were playing a hybrid of my favourite games, such as [b]S.T.A.L.K.E.R.[/b], [b]Fallout[/b], and [b]Cyberpunk 2077[/b], with some mechanics that even reminded me of [b]Helldivers[/b] and others.

Player design is also very impressive. You can easily recognize which type of shield and weapons your opponent is using just by looking at them when you are close. All these models are distinct and detailed, and even the secondary weapon is visible on the player‚Äôs shoulder, which adds a nice tactical touch and visual realism.

AI-controlled enemies are also impressive. They try to perform strategic flanking, change positions during fights, and react to you very quickly. Their ability to adapt to different situations and the environment is truly amazing.
Fights with other players can be quite intense. A lot depends on positioning, weapon choice, skill, reaction time, and of course, who has the best gear and knows how and when to use it.

The only really frustrating part is dying. You lose your entire inventory, except for one small pocket that sometimes automatically stores a random item. It can be a funny surprise to discover that you still had some ammo saved there. üòÑ I understand that this is normal for extraction shooters, but it still feels painful to lose all your precious guns and great finds that took time and energy to collect. They either end up in someone else‚Äôs hands or remain lying on the map if nobody needs them or has time to pick them up.

I would like to see more quests or tasks that encourage players to be at least sometimes friendly with each other. It would be nice to have some reward for extracting together, even if one of you is knocked out but still alive and carrying loot, or for fighting against ARCs as a team. This would create more moments of cooperation instead of everyone hunting players who are already being attacked by bots, finishing them off, or camping and sniping near extraction points.
I was really impressed when I watched videos from earlier playtests where people shouted [i]‚ÄúFriendly!‚Äù[/i] or [i]‚ÄúLet‚Äôs team up!‚Äù[/i] and then actually played together. They helped each other fight bots, extract, and even shared loot when someone needed an item for a quest. During the Server Slam, however, I did not hear anyone using proximity chat. I tried it a few times myself, but no one responded, so I gave up. I still helped other players from time to time to at least extract together without looting them, but others never did the same for us. Most people just shot on sight.
I can understand why. There were quests for damaging or killing other raiders, plus extra XP rewards for it, but no rewards at all for helping others. It is logical that players prefer to kill each other instead of cooperating.
[hr][/hr]
Despite that, I still had a great time exploring, fighting, and experiencing this world. The soundscape, the visual detail, and the atmosphere make every raid feel meaningful and unique. I really hope future updates bring more incentives for cooperation and make the world feel a little warmer and more alive. If that happens, this game could easily become one of the best and most memorable extraction shooters out there.

This game is visually beautiful, and has great performance on my rig at max settings.

I can only speak for the PVE aspect so far as I've only encountered a duo during extraction and a missile launching drone helped me take them out. That being said, the safer areas feel casual to loot and fight ARC drones in, and the medium areas feel more realistic. 

In the medium loot zones (yellow on the map), there are tons of drones, easy to take down a couple at once but in a group they can easily wipe you out. Medium zones feel like the bread and butter of the loot pool so far, being consistent with tier 1 and 2 weapons or uncommon rarity stuff. 

In the high loot zones, it feels like a genuine android apocalypse event, actual nightmare fuel. There are way more ARC enemies, and they are harder. Not just harder, but unless you have the right weapon type or throwables you will NOT beat them, and you will NOT escape them.

I don't feel much gear fear in this compared to similar games so far, but this play test map is smaller and it's only 1 of the full game playable maps. The in-game economy is fairly simple to understand but interestingly enough some items that are common rarity (white/grey) are more valuable than epic (purple/pink?) ones! 

There's no storm or closing circle to deal with yet in the game, not sure if something like that will get added to the main game play loop or if it would be a limited event or separate game mode. I see that night raids are a thing but I haven't tried them yet!

Unlike other games in the genre, this game places an extremely high importance on noise/sound... Everything you do makes noise, and everything you hear from breathing, footsteps, bushes rustling, doors/containers/drawers opening/closing, gunfire, reloading etc. can be heard not just by you but by everyone else AND the ARC drones! You have to think twice about vaulting/hurdling obstacles, opening/closing doors, Sure, firing your weapons in an extraction shooter game attracts other players, but in this one, you can hear others climbing ladders, looting containers, and even healing. I really enjoy how big of a role that audio plays in this game.

Overall, great game so far, big potential. Feels like a void is being filled for me as someone who found Tarkov too punishing, and found the cycle frontier too cartoon/arcade like.

Title: Arc Raiders: A Post-Apocalyptic Identity Crisis ‚Äì Not What I Expected

Having spent some time with Arc Raiders, I regret to say it largely missed the mark for me. While it boasts a polished facade, the experience underneath feels shallow and ultimately unfulfilling.

From a purely mechanical standpoint, the gameplay feels competent and modern. Character controls are standard for a third-person shooter, and visually, everything is well-executed. However, much of the core gameplay loop feels derivative, borrowing heavily from established formulas without adding anything truly unique or compelling.

My biggest issue, and where the game fundamentally fails for me, is its complete lack of immersion into the post-apocalyptic world it claims to inhabit. Despite the serious tone the game initially presented, from the very beginning, Arc Raiders constantly felt more like a vibrant, arcadey experience akin to Fortnite.

This isn't necessarily a problem for all games, but Arc Raiders marketed itself as something deep and serious, promising a gritty struggle for survival. Instead, it delivers a very surface-level engagement. This disparity between expectation and reality feels like a significant misrepresentation, one that I believe will disappoint a large segment of its potential player base.

On a more positive note, the game's graphics are quite good, and from a technical perspective, I encountered no significant issues with performance or stability.

Ultimately, Arc Raiders seems best suited for players who enjoy engaging with gameplay mechanics without needing a deep narrative or world to get lost in. If you approach games like competitive titles, where the surrounding atmosphere and story are secondary to pure action, you might find some enjoyment here. However, if you're looking for an immersive post-apocalyptic journey or a game that lives up to its initial serious promises, Arc Raiders is likely to leave you wanting more.

Not Recommended.

My biggest issue, and where the game fundamentally fails for me, is its complete lack of immersion into the post-apocalyptic world it claims to inhabit. Despite the serious tone the game initially presented, from the very beginning, Arc Raiders constantly felt more like a vibrant, arcadey experience akin to Fortnite.

This isn't necessarily a problem for all games, but Arc Raiders marketed itself as something deep and serious, promising a gritty struggle for survival. Instead, it delivers a very surface-level engagement. This disparity between expectation and reality feels like a significant misrepresentation, one that I believe will disappoint a large segment of its potential player base.

On a more positive note, the game's graphics are quite good, and from a technical perspective, I encountered no significant issues with performance or stability.

Ultimately, Arc Raiders seems best suited for players who enjoy engaging with gameplay mechanics without needing a deep narrative or world to get lost in. If you approach games like competitive titles, where the surrounding atmosphere and story are secondary to pure action, you might find some enjoyment here. However, if you're looking for an immersive post-apocalyptic journey or a game that lives up to its initial serious promises, Arc Raiders is likely to leave you wanting more.

Not Recommended.

Title: Arc Raiders: A Post-Apocalyptic Identity Crisis ‚Äì Not What I Expected

Having spent some time with Arc Raiders, I regret to say it largely missed the mark for me. While it boasts a polished facade, the experience underneath feels shallow and ultimately unfulfilling.

From a purely mechanical standpoint, the gameplay feels competent and modern. Character controls are standard for a third-person shooter, and visually, everything is well-executed. However, much of the core gameplay loop feels derivative, borrowing heavily from established formulas without adding anything truly unique or compelling.

My biggest issue, and where the game fundamentally fails for me, is its complete lack of immersion into the post-apocalyptic world it claims to inhabit. Despite the serious tone the game initially presented, from the very beginning, Arc Raiders constantly felt more like a vibrant, arcadey experience akin to Fortnite.

This isn't necessarily a problem for all games, but Arc Raiders marketed itself as something deep and serious, promising a gritty struggle for survival. Instead, it delivers a very surface-level engagement. This disparity between expectation and reality feels like a significant misrepresentation, one that I believe will disappoint a large segment of its potential player base.

On a more positive note, the game's graphics are quite good, and from a technical perspective, I encountered no significant issues with performance or stability.

Ultimately, Arc Raiders seems best suited for players who enjoy engaging with gameplay mechanics without needing a deep narrative or world to get lost in. If you approach games like competitive titles, where the surrounding atmosphere and story are secondary to pure action, you might find some enjoyment here. However, if you're looking for an immersive post-apocalyptic journey or a game that lives up to its initial serious promises, Arc Raiders is likely to leave you wanting more.

Not Recommended.
